The popularity of cryptocurrencies has led to an increase in the number of fraud and related crimes, which is also evident in non-financial institutions.

NFTs, which are linked to a blockchain, are becoming increasingly popular as Wall Street and Hollywood investors jump on the bandwagon.

In 2021, more than €38.8 billion in cryptocurrencies were transferred to NFT-related smart contracts, up from €93 million the previous year.

Fake Volume (Wash Trading)

Wash trading (also known as “fake volume”) is a method of manipulating the value and liquidity of an asset that is illegal under the laws of many countries. It is a common practice on bitcoin exchanges trying to increase trading volume.

According to experts, selling a token to a wallet that already owns it is a relatively simple operation in this small universe where no one is forced to reveal their identity.

In 2021, the corporation found that even though the vast majority of people who tried wash trading failed, those who did succeed made a fortune.

Only 41% of the 262 wash trading activities were profitable, despite generating more than €7.8 million in revenue. The remainder suffered a loss of approximately 500,000.

According to the research findings, NFT (fake volume) wash trading is illegal. “However, although wash trading is prohibited in traditional markets, it has not yet been investigated in non-traditional markets…. We ask NFT platforms to prohibit this type of behavior.”

money laundering

Money laundering has long been a concern in traditional banking, but has now spread to digital assets, drawing the ire of law enforcement around the world.

Illegitimate addresses sent more than €2.6 million to NFT markets last year, a significant increase from less than €441,000 the previous year. During the second and third quarters of 2021, the vast majority of this activity came from addresses associated with fraud.

In one case in the fourth quarter, some 250,000 euros in bitcoins were transferred from Chatex, a virtual cryptocurrency exchange where suspects of money laundering, terrorism and drug trafficking are found.

Aside from these two approaches, crooks use a variety of different techniques. Those are the two areas experts have focused on, according to Kim Grauer, as they are “pretty basic” to assess on the blockchain, he added.

He said the industry hasn’t been around long enough to witness the kind of fraud and ripping off users that is going on right now. “We anticipate that 2022 will be an important year for NFT crimes, and we will actively monitor the situation”.
